Award.AwardTitle: Conference on "Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations: Recent Developments and Future Directions"
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Fefferman, 1402227):

This award provides partial funding for a three-day Conference on "Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations: Recent Developments and Future Directions", to be held September 19-21, 2014, at the University of Chicago.

The conference focuses on a number of different areas of partial differential equations where harmonic analysis techniques are often used, with emphasis on recent developments in non-linear dispersive PDE, inverse problems, elliptic homogenization and boundary value problems. The key issues are global well-posedness and blow up, profile decomposition, soliton resolution conjecture, unique continuation properties, Calderon problem with partial data, anisotropic inverse problems, uniform boundary regularity estimates, etc. Several world leading experts are confirmed as participants and will give lectures. The conference organizers aim to attract a broad range of participants including junior researchers and members of underrepresented groups. The achievements and impacts of Carlos Kenig in analysis will be celebrated in the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference was a complete success. All the invited speakers delivered wonderful talks and those who used a power point delivery tool allowed us to post their slides in the conference web page at http://math.mit.edu/conferences/kenig/speakers.php.

There were three main areas of mathematics that were presented and that were all substantially advanced by the work of Carlos Kenig, who we celebrated during the conference. These areas were: Dispersive equations, elliptic equations and inverse problems. 

The attendance was fantastic. We calculated that on Saturday there were more than 200 participants. Among them several junior researchers, who were supported either by the Clay Mathematical Institute or by the NSF.

After the conference we asked the junior researchers to send us testimonials, we  report some of them below. We think they are the best proof that this meeting was timely, had a collection of fantastic speakers, the lectures were beautifully delivered, they were extremely interesting and extremely useful to the young mathematicians.

  1. The lineup of speakers was nothing short of excellent... I have never in the same place as so many brilliant and successful mathematicians. This, of course, includes many outside of the list of speakers. It was a very productive time for me to make new acquaintances and reinforce relationships, with both younger and more experienced mathematicians. It was very stimulating.        
    All of the accommodations were very good, including the hotel and coffee breaks. The administrative side, with regards to registration, planning and reimbursement, also ran very smoothly.
  2. The conference at Chicago was the most exciting scientific event of my year. Not only was I happy to see most of my top 100 mathematician friends, who drive the field forward, but the atmosphere was singularly positive and productive. The talks were clear and well motivated. I clearly want to get involved in a variety of new projects as a result. I also got at least two collaborations restarted and rejuvenated. It turned out that a result of mine may be of use a former colleague Luda Korobenko, who attended the conference and she may help me to finish up a long running project. I received several invitations to visit: Buffalo, McMaster, Santa Barbara to name a few. It is exciting to continue the conversations we had in Chicago, share some recent work and exchange ideas. And most importantly, I feel excited about mathematics that we do and their broad applications.
  3. It was a great conference. It created chances for young graduate students and postdocs all over the world to meet each other and talk to the world experts. The talks were wonderful and covered cutting topics in analysis and PDE. It seems that I have found a new collaborator and might produce a new result soon.
  4. The conference in honor of Carlos Kenig was a great opportunity for young researchers to get an overview of the impressive work that has been done in the field of Partial Differential Equations and Harmonic Analysis and how it tied in to the pioneering work of Professor Kenig. The organizers did a great job of selecting a wide variety of talks. The talks presented works of the highest level of technical skill in a clear and understandable way. Attending such a conference is a very valuable for any aspiring young researcher. The travel support offered by the Clay Mathematics Institute was well-appreciated.
